description:
Recommend: Pork dumpling, Shrimp & Chives dumpling, pork sticky rice balls

If you're looking for a quick & cheap takeout dimsum, look no further than Happy Bakery. How does it differ from other takeout dimsum places? The dumplings stay intact. I've noticed at other dimsum places, the dumplings have been oversteamed to the point where the clear wrapping starts sticking to other dumplings, thus ripping the dumpling apart. 

Parking on Irving is metered parking, but I normally circle around the residential areas until I find free parking.
author: Charissa S.

description:
This review has been a long time coming.  In this case though, it's not because I came here years ago and never got around to writing my review.  Rather, it's because I came here years ago, have been back countless times since then, and I STILL haven't written my review.  It's subtle, but there's a difference - this is an ongoing thing!  You know, just in case I decided to give a different rating.  Yeah, that's why I haven't done this until now...ha!

Now, despite what their name might suggest, Happy Bakery isn't your "cakes and cookies"-sort of bakery.  Rather, think more like har gow and siu mai, as it's more of a "dim sum to-go" type of joint.  What sets them apart from similar spots along Irving, though?  The other half of the business - a Chinese to-go counter where you can get a bunch of deli staples, such as chow fun, chow mein, fried rice, fried chicken wings, sweet & sour pork, braised tofu, and so much more (though no char siu, roast duck, or roast pork, unfortunately).

While I've picked up food from both of their counters, I frequent their dim sum one far more often.  Not that any of their hot foods that I've tried have been bad; in fact, their drumsticks and wings are actually pretty solid (crispy, albeit oily).  It's just that nearly all of the other hot foods I've tried have been unremarkable, like their chow mein.  On the other hand, I've enjoyed nearly everything from their dim sum side, especially their siu mai (meaty, juicy) and fairly unique sticky rice balls (SO GOOD!).

Though I can see how people may not be overwhelmed by the food here, I find it surprising that so many people have shaved off stars because of the service.  Beyond how I've never had any problems, shouldn't it be kind of expected that workers aren't going to be overly friendly, given the reputation of Chinese eateries.  Sure, they skip the pleasantries, but it's not like they're outright rude.

Based purely on taste, Happy Bakery fits the exact definition of a THREE AND A HALF STAR rating - three stars for the Chinese deli side, four stars for the dim sum side.  However, factoring in their prices (3 items for $2.20-$2.50, depending on what you choose), it's an easy call to round up to four.  Even though traditional dim sum joints might taste better, it's hard to argue with paying half the price (or less!) while eating from the comfort of my own home.
author: Mike L.

description:
Whenever I'm in town I love to come here straight from the airport to pick up breakfast goodies to devour at home close by - we usually get their jook/congee, beef siu mai, har gaw and baked bbq pork buns. 

Decent bang for your buck, food quality has been consistent for the 5+ years my family has been coming here, and convenient location. 

Customer service may be hit or miss but honestly - at these types of places, if I'm getting the food I asked for and get correct change back, I'm a happy camper haha. 

Parking is harried depending on the time of day you go, as it is Irving street after all. And if you want to pick up their congee, aim for earlier in the day as it is traditionally a breakfast food and may run out. Cash only!
author: Jaclyn L.

description: Good for a quick can't say cheap but affordable lunch!  Not the cleanest place. But for you fast fix of point to order foods and Asian pastries...
author: Paul G.

description:
I got some pretty tasty stuff here last weekend!
I've been looking around for a place on my side of the park for a while and this place was pretty well reviewed; it was also the cleanest place around for a few blocks.

I got shrimp dumplings, Steamed BBQ Pork Buns and some BBQ pork Chow Mein. All fairly tasty. The Chow Mein was fairly greasy but tasted good and wasn't overly salted.

The only drawback of eating here was you had to go to two lines and pay twice (for different things) but that wasn't really a big deal.
author: Tom S.

description: I enjoyed the easy access of this bakery. I stopped by for a pork bun. Cheap, quick and tasty. I definitely want to go back for lunch menu. I walked by a few times the other day and there is always a line of customers to order. That looks promising.
author: Aya T.

description:
I thought it was a great bargain when I saw the 2 meal combo with rice for only $6, but they won't allow you to get fried rice, only the steamed rice and YOU BETTER LIKE A LOT OF RICE because they put LOTS of it in the plastic carton.  They don't give much of the 2 meals.  Because I don't like getting fat with lots of tasteless carbs AND because I don't like eating 5 times more steamed rice than veggies/meat, I had to throw away nearly an entire plate of steamed rice.  

So I went to the dim sum area to see if it was any better.  Nope, same thing.  The chicken/mushroom/boiled egg steamed bun didn't have any real taste - the buns on Clement St/6th ave are a lot tastier with tastier filling/sauces.  The shrimp dumplings were barely filled with tiny shrimp and the dumpling pouches themselves came apart easily with holes in them.  

The eatery isn't bad, but it doesn't compare as far as portion size & tastiness to Sweet Delight bakery on Mission St/Excelsior or even Wing Lee on Clement St.
author: Frugal C.

description: Just went in to order a rice with 2 items plate. Told the lady in mandarin that I didnt want rice and to substitute it with noodles and I got 2 different tofu items. One tofu stuffed with meat and the other green bean stir fry with tofu. The lady says in Cantonese, thinking I didnt understand, to the other lady that I didnt want rice and instead ordered 2 different tofu. So what if I did? I am paying for it and not like I'm forcing her to eat it. They are so rude! And at least make sure a person doesnt understand before speaking rudely of others.
author: R O.

description: My go to for cheap meat and vegetables buns + dimsum. $20 will get you a full bag of food! The thick lo mein by the pound is delicious...service could be better, but what can you expect when you can get 3 shrimp dumplings for $2!!!
author: Julie W.

description:
Best steamed large chicken buns, fried pork dumplings and Chinese tamales. 

Pretty good fried chicken wings too.
author: Piggy W.

description: My kids & I love the food here! They have the best steamed buns & take out dim sum. Then the other side has very good to-go variety of chow meins & fried rice. Their veggies are always fresh & their fried drumsticks & fried fish are made well. We get 2 bags of food from there 2-3x/month.
author: Tammie C.

description: My go-to for dim sum to go. Very well priced. Sticky rice and chicken wrapped in a banana leaf here is classic. Shrimp dumplings are great too. Cash only
author: Sid D.

description:
0 stars if I could, and I think wouldn't have written this review except that:

1.They have the WORST.  I mean the WORST customer service. They just all seem like bitter old women. Multiple experiences (personal and hearing from others). They are rude af. One time I waited in line and they skipped me. I told them, no I really was waiting. The other customer agreed with me, and the old dimsum lady COMPLETELY ignored me and moved on to the next customer. I just left.

2. THEIR employees go to TC Pastry for lunch. I saw one walk over (still in her white plastic apron) today but it was closed for July 4th. LOL If your place is so good why do you need to go to another dimsum location where they sell the same exact thing? This speaks VOLUMES to the quality of this place. 

3. As for the food, which probably deserves half a star - IT'S GENERIC, you can get it anywhere. Again, reread #2 as proof of what their OWN employees think of their food. Pretty. hilarious.
author: Kay U.

description: A lady working in there is unbelievable rude. Don't ever go there. You may feel quite offended and it may ruin your day. could be the worst service you can ever have!
author: Amy J.

description: I have also discovered in the last couple of years that I love their soy sauce chicken wings and their noodles from the right side of the restaurant. Quick and easy family dinner.
author: Ping N.

description: This place doesn't deserve even 1 star. Their servers are extremely rude!! Been there several times and nothing has changed. I had found a chunk of steel wool in my food back in their opening week. Went back The following day to show my concern to the owners ( husband and wife). They just started talking in Chinese and seems like they didn't care. 2nd time after couple of months I gave it another try. I was enjoying my lunch when this lady wearing gloves from the kitchen came out and scooped some food out from their display using her hand and ran back inside. (Gross). It took me couple of years to go back. Today I ordered some sweet and sour pork over rice. I asked the server to give me some chicken from the top part coz its a little crispier than the one she was giving me, off course what else is new??? She gave me an attitude while saying NO TOP! NO CRISPY!! JUST THIS!! SMH  I've never learned my lesson..lol
author: Gigi C.

description: I'll give a zero if it's possible. I walked out the store immediately after the waitress knocked on the wall rudely showing me the prize WITHOUT SAYING A WORD. Terrible service
author: Xin Z.

description:
I'm a fan of their sew mai (my fave: beef over pork over chicken in order of preference) and the bok tong gou (not for me, for the other half).  The har gow are not as enticing to me as the sew mai , but very serviceable.  

I see a lot of kvetching about the service... it's perfunctory, people... get used to it.  You order, you get, you don't make small talk, you don't discuss sports.  My orders have always been filled efficiently.  

N.B.: It's cash only.  An Asian trio in front of me tried to pay with a CC, when that failed, the two guys suggested TC (across the street) and I pointed out they're cash only also.  The female of the trio does the hands-on hip thang and says, "you need a white guy to tell you that?  Sheesh!"
author: Bruce B.

description: I was at TC Bakery across the street yesterday. I'm here today to compare. The price points are about the same and so for the taste of the country is more or less the same. Either place is terribly clean and both run by middle-aged Chinese women on a spectrum of crankiness. The congee is actually OK (4/5) stars if you do not mind eating out of a plastic bowl and using plastic forks. At less than three dollars a bowl, it is actually very good value. Between the two places I don't know which one I would choose.
author: Leung T.

description: Really wanted to like this place since it seems like good food. I got the lunch 2 choice with rice special (eggplant and green beans with chicken) which was tasty but I almost swallowed a huge piece of plastic I found 3/4 into the meal. The ladies on this side of the restaurant are nice but I can't bring myself to go back if I find dirty plastic in my food. On the Dim sum side, only got shrimp gow which was good but the lady on that side was super grumpy and yelled at me for not understanding the poor price signs they have. When I asked her to clarify the prices she mumbled and didn't answer my questions so I just ordered what I saw on the sign and then when I asked to clarify the total bill, she was like I told you this price for some are higher (which she didn't). If she's going to be angry at customers for not understanding her signs, maybe she needs to fix them. And I even tried clarifying prices in mandarin hoping language consistency would help her be less angry but she was hostile in both languages.
author: m s.

description:
I don't consider Happy Bakery to be particularly cheap. They sell their food for $4.80/lb ($4.50 plus tax). And yes, they have those lunch specials (2 items plus rice) for $5.75 but Hing Wang on 8th & Judah gives you more portions for cheaper. TC Bakery across the street also sells 3-item dim sum at a cheaper price too. With that said, Happy Bakery has a larger and better selection of entrees and smaller dim sum items. They sell at least 6 different kinds of noodles here and some amazing deep fried chicken. My favorite item is the rice rolls cooked with green onions and tons of soy sauce.

Overall, 3 stars seems pretty low considering I come here at least once a week. But it's really not the kind of place I'd recommend except out of convenience.
author: Tiffany H.

description:
I personally love this place. Dim sum is always on point. Har gow has fat shrimps, bamboo shoots, and wrapper is prepared wonderfully. Everything else is great too. I think majority is $2.10 for 3 pieces. Plus they have that $5.50 lunch special of rice and 2 sides. Nice variety and always fresh and yummy. 

Service is what you'd expect when you order to go dim sum in Chinatown. No biggie. 

Def come back. I always come back.
author: Elaine S.

description: Can I leave zero star? I am not paying for the service even they have good food. But the truth is the worst dim sum in town.
author: Sammi Z.

description: They have the worst customer service in town. The employees are very rude to customers if you don't speak Chinese, especially the skinny tall lady with the short hair. I would fire her instantly if I were the owner. Food is Ok. There are better a dim Sum shops in this area. Will never go back.
author: Ha D.

description: I've been here a few times before and it was good enough for me to return. Yesterday's experience was totally different... I bought dim sum for dinner around 3pm. When I got home, the Siu Mai and Beef Balls were RAW.
author: Robby S.

description: Their shrimp dumpling is okay but their shu mai is discussing. Definitely, will be the last time here.
author: Aniko N.

description:
It's been awhile since I've been to Happy Bakery. I enjoy eating there because they have the $5 lunch special that has rice with 2 sides or noodles with 1 side. 

My experience there today was not as good as usual. I asked for rice, and the 2 sides; sweet and sour chicken and tofu. However, what I got was 3/4 rice, a tiny scoop of chicken and tofu. I was disappointed at the terrible portiom distibution. Hopefully next time I go, ill get a bigger portion of sides.
author: Tiffany L.

description:
I always go to the lunch/dinner section and get fried chicken with tofu and white rice. The price is extremely reasonable and the food is always great. I'll come here again if I'm feeling lazy to get lunch. 

I've also tried their ha gow and it didn't disappoint!

The only downside is that the employees give bad customer service and are not patient with old customers.
author: Kathy D.

description: I never expect good service from a Chinese place but this is the worst I have seen.  Their had terrible attitude and hung up on me when i asked a couple of questions while ordering large amount of food for a party.  If I could give negative stars, it would be negative 5 stars!
author: Irene Y.

description:
We made the mistake of buying dim sum from this place instead of TC Bakery which we found out after the fact is across the street!  We're familiar with the TC Bakery location in Daly City; we like their dim sum as its consistent and very affordable.  However, we  got our wires crossed from hearsay information from a family member who raved about a dim sum place by '25th & Irving'.  Unfortunately we weren't given the name & we neglected to ask not realizing there are two of them on the same block but across the street from the other.  And wow we sure made an expensive mistake.

Firstly, as is typical, there is non-service.  One is lucky if the dim sum clerk acknowledges you with your non-Cantonese/non-Chinese knowledge.  But the clerk was okay (for this type of place).  I read some older reviews of the nasty service, but maybe we're so used to the typical lack of courtesy that's commonplace in Chinese places we're immune to it now.  But honestly the clerk could have been worse.

The worst thing was the dim sum itself.  We wasted $38 on food that was poorly made and tasteless.  The har gow looked attractive as it was large, however, it tasted of rice flour mostly since there was hardly any shrimp; the shrimp mixture only had a few chopped pieces of bamboo shoot-no water chestnut nor sesame oil as TC's.  The baked BBQ pork buns were awful.  The dough was pasty, and the filling was not only orangey but the meat was tasteless.  There was a smaller steamed bun that had veg. & pork filling; however, the potstickers had the exact same mixture.  And the potstickers were the worst ever I've tasted.  The dough was thick and chewy & very unpleasant like stale.  The siu mai was just okay.  

Thus, definitely we'll never return to the (Un) Happy Bakery & go to TC Pastry.
author: Luisa T.

description:
I usually shop here for dim sum, porridge, and lunch. March 21, 2016
I went to get chicken mushroom porridge. Brought it home and start eating and I found a baby cockroach in the porch. I was so surprised that it was in my porridge . I threw the whole thing out. I'm not sure should I tell them! Last time there was fly landed on their pastry. I told the lady that the fly landed on their food, and all she Took her tongs swing it around so the fly would fly away. Then she asked me which pastry do you want. I told her I didn't want it had a fly on it. She did care! Wow
author: Marie W.

description: Never come to this place! Horrible service with very bad attitude! The order total was $20 with some changes. We gave her $20 first then we were trying to find change to make it easier, the women said we didn't give any money to her with soooooo bad attitude! I hate this place! And the owner absolutely need to watch the employees here! This place will be out of business soon, if they keep doing this!
author: Lynn W.

description:
Happy Bakery is located on a busy corner on Irving St. We just happen to walk by and noticed all this freshly baked Bao's and and cooked food on a Hot table. There were lots of people in line ordering dim sum and pastries. Being the foodies that we are we had to try it, even though we just had lunch at Marnee Thai just next door. 

We ordered the Chinese sausage bun, black bean pork ribs, the egg custard pastry and the stir fry rice noodles. The quality of the food was not the best but the price was defiantly right. I can see why there is a line
author: George F.

description: THE WORST SERVICE EVER!!!!!!!! They always seem angry and whenever you ask something, they'll look at you like your retard. They sometimes over charge you cuz they can't do simple addition... DON'T GO HERE
author: Ellen W.

description:
Don't come here expecting great service with a smile, cushy seats, candlelight, white table clothed tables.
DO come here to get some delicious, moist dim sum and quick service!
This is my favorite spot for dim sum in the sunset district! Consistent, favorful shrimp dumplings, chive dumplings, and shu mai. The steamed buns have never disappointed either!! 
For $5-$6 you can get a filling meal!
author: Olivia B.

description:
This is a regular stop for me on my trips to San Francisco! I love how it's open very early in the morning, and the food is delicious while also being cheap! I've had both the dim sum and the lunch items there.

DIM SUM
They have a variety of items, but I mainly go here for the large buns filled with chicken, chinese sausage, egg, etc. I'm not sure what the exact name is, but it's the largest bun they have. It's absolutely delicious and unlike other places, they don't skimp on the meat. There's plenty of filling and the buns are huge!

LUNCH ITEMS
I've gotten dim sum here for years now, but this was my first time trying the lunch special. It still amazes me that even at 9am, the lunch items are ready to go! I tried this thick noodle chow mein (don't know the exact name since the dishes aren't always labeled) as well as the thin noodle chow mien as well. Both were slightly heavy in flavor but still delicious. They also give you HUGE portions. I plan on going back and trying their fried rice and side dishes next time!
author: Aye K.

description: 3 for $1.90 dim sum! The quality is not as good as restaurants, but for the cheap price its not bad either! Good choice if you just want to get dim sum to-go!
author: Victoria T.

description:
They have really good shrimp dim sum!
3 for 1.95! Also the pork porridge is only $3 for a pretty decent sized container. I paid $5~ earlier at hang ah tea dim sum so the price is definitely better here, but what isn't great is the quality. Definitely price is what determines good food in SF in my opinion.
author: Eric H.

description:
Thank goodness for a dim sum place to be open at 7am, so I can rush in and get me some breakfast before driving all the way to Marin for work.

The lady isn't particularly friendly, but I'm there for the dim sum, not her. My favorites are the beef ball, shark fin gow, ha gow (shrimp dumpling), and the siu mai (pork dumpling). Price is decent.

Ample parking at 7am, but other than that it's a headache to find parking on Irving.
author: V M.

description: Best dim sum for cheap price! Just try their chowcho dumplings and curry pastry. There's usually a line so make sure you know what you want to order because the servers don't have a lot of patience.
author: Eggie S.

description: I have been coming here all the time  but from now on never again , what happened was on 6/23/16 I got there about 9 am and i was in line then a Chinese lady with short hair cut no smile on her face so she asked me what you need? I said 1 porridge then she said whats next I said 2 chicken buns pls , I asked do you have wheat buns she said what ? I repeated and she didn't answer , again I said do you  know wheat buns ? She said no I don't know with a wasn't awake up on her face or maybe she's like that all the times , terrible customer service , I meant who wants to see that face in the morning and attitude bad luck all day , from now on I go cross street from them much better great customer service that's the way they are  , the place call Happy bakery ! But not happy people in there , I feel sorry for those kind of unhappy faces they shouldn't be there
author: Kathy N.

description: I only come for their Chinese tamales...they don't stick a bunch of pork fat and other random crap like other places. I just freeze them and bring them out of a quick lunch or dinner option.
author: Elaine Y.

description: I came here after work. Dim sum tastes OK. Not really that good. It's super cheap! I ate inside, they served with no water or hot tea. This place is good for order to go.
author: T B.

description: If you're on this side of town this is where I go to get my cheap dim sum fix. Great selection. Great prices. I buy about fifty dollars worth of stuff when I'm here. Steamed pork buns , egg tarts , Mochi egg tarts , yu taio fried donut, siu mai, har gow, etc.
author: Lily F.

description:
Two stars may be a bit too much for this place. I'm one who usually have patience for Chinese places considering that I know the culture quite well and Chinese are born to be blunt. Bad services seems to be a second nature to people who work at the entree side. 

Truthfully, food is ok but I don't think I need to spend my hard earned money so they can be rude to me everytime. Do they not understand that their customers are the ones who's keeping them employed?

I asked for a smaller portion of wings and the lady with a pony tail said there's a minimum. Well, it's only two more then I asked for and I told her that they used to sell it in smaller portions. She went on telling me that there's inflation and that they'll loose money. Well, they just lost my business I told her calmly. She went and started talking about me with her coworker. I told her if she's going to talk about me, she should at least wait until I leave. She then said that she's only chatting with her coworker and that its non of my business. Well, I truly thank her for saying that because it will no longer be my interest to walk into that place ever again. 

By the way, people on the dim sum side is much nicer.
author: Jane A.

description: I think the hot food side is better than the dimsum side, in terms of both selection and quality. Their ha gao (shrimp dumpling) is really good, but bbq pork bun ($1 each) didnt have that much filling. It was big, but thats about it. Bbq pork turn over wasnt that great either, but the noodle rolls were good. I wouldnt mind coming back, but would probably want to try another place in Inner Sunset. There are so many Asian places here! Do get the chicken drum stick tho. OMG the skin is SO crispy and it is huge! That was probably my favorite thing from here. If you're gonna try anything from here, I'd recommend the chicken drumstick the most :D
author: Katie S.

description:
My favorite dim sum counter.  Hai gow (3 pieces for $2.28) were smaller than Chinatown's Good Mong Kok Bakery's hai gow (which are priced the same), but wrappers are thinner, for those who prefer that, and the shrimp has a hint of white pepper perhaps which I liked.

Pork jook/porridge is $3.50 for plastic bucket full.  Thinner consistency than I prefer, but super hot and fresh (even when ordered near end of afternoon).
author: Thom S.

description: Boxed combo box $5.75 for tiny portions of food, 2!small scoop of food over rice better to go to any of the 3 Chinese deli's on Clement Street 6th to 8th Ave  instead bAvoid this place. Even the bakery items are small and expensive. 点心分类贵也不好吃。
author: Will L.

description: Another good dim sum place on Irving for a quick bite. They have dumplings, buns, and hot food like chow mein and spareribs. I like their drumsticks. Yeah they're oily but they're big and tasty...probably from the msg though.  A 2 item lunch box w/ either noodles or rude is usually around $6...? Not sure if they raised the price. Good deal.
author: Julie L.

description: Cheap doesn't mean you can be impatient. Owner is unwilling to provide good quality of customer service just  because everything is cheap.
author: William T.

description: Some of the staffs treat Costumers with very pool attitude. I hope the store owner will check your staff behaviors if you wanted customers to be happy to supporting your business.
author: Chan S.

description:
The food here is cheap and pretty good. I usually get the chow fun and garlicky green beans on the right side. On the left side, I get the steamed pork bao and the pork sticky rice balls (my fave!). I like that their bao are kind of small because maybe i'm weird, but I feel like the big ones don't always get the bread to meat ratio right. 
Don't bother with the sweet rice cakes here. I'm not sure what it is, but they aren't that great.
author: Hanster P.

description: Been to the dim sum side of this place on and off for years.  The dim sum is okay, nothing fancy here.  This place does get crowded during lunch hour.
author: Guest U.

description:
I've written over 320 reviews and this is my second one-star review. This place has all the makings of a great Chinese hole in the wall dim sum place -- extremely rude servers, check; cash only, check; good food...oh wait a minute... 

I wanted to try out the dim sum place across the street (TC Pastry), but they were closed for two weeks for vacation. I was hunkering for some good dim sum so when I saw this place across the street, I thought that must be a sign. The place had a good amount of patrons so I dismissed the three star rating and went in. Well, I was certainly disappointed because the food was atrocious!

First of all, their portion sizes of dim sum is at least 15% smaller than any other places that I've ordered. The shrimp dumpling had thick mushy wrapper and barely any shrimp. The beef dumplings were ok, but the level of flavor was pretty muted compared to other places. With subpar food, the eye rolling from the server really riled me. How they managed to survive in the Richmond is beyond me. I certainly won't make the mistake of patronizing this place again!
author: Alice W.

description: Ordered the egg tart with egg white.  It came out warm with the nice fresh flaky crust.  Perfect
author: Chris P.

description:
I go here all the time to get the big chicken buns filled with chicken, one sausage, and one mushroom, and one egg white. It's really big and the buns are delicious. 

The only issue I had is that there was  a piece of human hair on the bun twice out of the 100 buns that I have bought from here.  So no bueno on that!!

The other foods here are decent too and fresh. If you go late, they run out of big buns though and other items! 

When I eat, I'm happy so Happy Bakery gets four stars!
author: Gangsta G.

description:
First of all,

Everyone. Be real. You don't come here to get Michelin Star Dim Sum and Chinese Cuisine. You come here because you want to grab something quick to eat or take it to go for lunch. That being said, the fairest comparison for happy bakery is to compare it to all the other Chinese Dimsum x-press and Chinese Deli food places in the area (although this places doesn't serve BBQ items). So here's the lowdown

Dim Sum
Most items are $1.80 per order. You have your Har Gow, Siu Mai, Guo Tie, Shark Fin Gow, Lo Mai Gai, etc. Then you have your sweeter items like cherng fun and dan tat. Next is baked items like Nai Wong Bao, Cha Siu Bao, Po Lo Bao. I would say everything here is generally good but it really depends on what time you go and whether you come at the right now when a fresh batch comes out of the kitchen. The best time to go would be in the morning when its the freshest. I will have to say, in my dim sum eating experience( having been to over 20 yum cha places and dim sum restaurants in San Francisco, Los Angeles, Irvine, & San Diego) this place HANDS DOWN has the BEST Har Gow. The dumpling itself is chewy and the shrimp filling is juicy and plump.

Chinese Takeout
This place offers 2 items with white rice for $4.50(additional items extra). I don't know about you but this is a great deal for takeout lunch. What this place is good at is presentation. Yes its cheap food but the counter itself is well maintained and there are no scraps of food all over the place. They also clean the area well so you feel like your eating relatively clean food. I recommend getting the Pai Gwut, Chicken with Mushroom, Fried Tofu, and Curry.

This place is pretty good compared to others so its worth a shot. I've been coming here for 7 years and bad experiences seem few and far between.
author: James K.

description:
My go-to place for quick chinese food or dim sum to-go. 

I always do take out.

Today's review is for the chinese noodle and side dish section. There are two doors, one door is for noodle and chinese food and the other door is for dim sum. Order and pay separately. 

They advertise white rice with two chinese items for $4.61. So exactly $5 after taxes. But I think the unadvertised deal is better, which is fried rice or noodle with one chinese item also for $5 (after taxes). I really really really like the fried thin rice noodle with shreds of meat here. It is not oily and very tasty. My second favorite is the soy sauce thick rice noodle crepe. But this is a little more greasy. And I think any chinese side item you pick is pretty good. So take a look and pick a side item such as eggplants, pepper short ribs, broccoli and beefs, fried tofu, fried chicken drum stick, or sweet and sour pork. You can't go wrong.
author: Janice T.

description:
Happiness is subjective. 

What makes us happy varies: friends. Money. Beer. More beer. Whatever.
For me to tell someone else what makes them happy with be rude and I am in no position to judge (outloud, at least).

Happy bakery sits happily on irving near my office. I walk by often and smile for a few reasons. Most notable reasons being "$4.83+tax for 2 item with rice" printed, in good ol' American English, on their window. The other reason being their green awning; green = money.... Money = beer.... Beer = happy ryan.

Today, feeling adventurous of all things new and happy, I decided to wear a happy smile and walk into happy bakery.

Instead, what I got was a dirty little Chinese food court minus hairnets with a side of 'tude. I was the only white dude in the place so it must be good! AMIRITE?! Wrong bro. wrong.

I got eggplant chicken, what looked like a pork chop and rice. Im not sure who came up with the price of $4.83 but they were a genius... because I was feeling cheap but hungry and this did the job.
I leave feeling unhappy with a happy wallet and skipped over the my office.

The food was what I expected, mediocre MSG infused Chinese cafeteria food. This is where happiness comes to die as you are deemed to be dead tired for the remainder of your glorious work day.

Pro tip: happy bakery also doubles as a laxative. How I ate solid food yet still pee'd out of my ass within a few hours still continues to puzzle me. Drank a lot the night before? Come here and pee all that fernet out of your anus... thank me later.

All in all. Standard, greasy ass cleansing Chinese grub.
author: Ryan L.

description: Their food was good, then popularity caused a decrease in quality. Then everything else collapsed.
author: M C.

description:
On the right side, they sell lunch and on the left, it's more dimsum like. For the lunch side, they have chow mein, rice, veggies, meats & etc. Dimsum side, they have bak tong gao (white rice sugar cake?), haw gow, siu mai (3 for $1.50?), egg tarts, various types of baos (most are $.80), jook (rice porridge for less than $2), donuts for jook...

One time, my cousin bought $20 worth of bak tong gao & between the 4 or 5 of us, we ate half of it in one sitting, it was SO GOOD!!!

Baos are usually big and I can never eat more than one, my fav are steamed (baked buns are too sweet) BBQ pork bun & veggie meat bun.

The "Dai Bao" (big bao) comes with mushroom, half an egg, meats, veggies & that one is GINORMOUS but only $1.50 which can fill me up. My sis can eat one and not eat anything else for a meal, sometimes she can't even finish it. One Dai Bao and an egg tart, she's content.
 
I remember getting the donuts for jook and it tasted fine but according to my aunt and dad, it smelled like alkaline?, so they made me throw it away.

I would recommend any kind of bao, haw gaos, bak tong gao...anything I've had so far is good except the donuts.

Lunch side, for only $4.15+tax you get rice & 2 items which is the special displayed on their front window. They've raised their prices, but it's still cheaper than Panda Express. Panda Express will probably only get you 1 item for that price.

I don't know if my dad knows the people, but I remember getting like a pound of BBQ pork (which is only 1 item) that came with my lunch special. That was so worth it, normally a pound of BBQ pork is about $7 or more, I'm estimating...I like how the choy seems so bland and healthy, it's like I made it at home, and oil wasn't used too much.
author: Kylie L.

description: I'd go there for the chicken bun every day!!! My boyfriend and I just fell in love with this affordable yummy bakery. It's as good as Golden Gate Bakery in the old China Town, in our opinion.
author: Kylie C.

description:
Damn!  We should of eaten here instead of Marnee Thai which was a couple of stores down.  After having dry and unsatisfying Thai food, we were still hungry and ordered Dim Sum from here while drooling over the hot plates across from the bakery.  If only we had secondary stomachs and store food for later, but we don't and that would be gross.  Live and learn.  Time to move on! 

Business must be good here because Pork BBQ buns were sold out quick!
author: Anthony E.

description: Chicken combo bun and the pork and peanut tamale are really good.
author: Josh G.

description: Decent food and take away dim sum. But the rudest, most unpleasant service. Especially the woman who works on the hot dishes side. I try not to go they unless I really am in a hurry for a bite to eat.
author: Priscilla C.

description:
Since they are located on Irving St, parking is difficult. It's an extremely tiny hole-in-the wall that sells fairly good dim sum for to-go. Reminds me of the shops in SF Chinatown. What's nice is that they have a list of what they sell behind them in both Chinese & English.

Our Order:
Bak Tong Gou (Sweet Honeycombed White Rice Cake)
Har Gow (Shrimp Dumplings)
Lo Bak Gou (Turnip Cake)
Gai Bao (Steamed Chicken Bun)

Able to get lots of items that were yummy & filling, all for less than $10! They have Ma Tai Gou (Water Chestnut Cake) as well which is another fave of mine that I'll try next time if I'm in the area.

Cash only.
author: Kitty K.

description:
I have been going here on and off for years.   The food is usually really good, and cheap (dim sum prices are 3 pieces for $1.80, pork buns for about $1.00, and a can of soda for $1.00).

Typically, the restaurant would be a 4 out of 5.  The place is a bit messy, but it is a hole in the wall dim sum bakery off of a busy street.  What it lacks in appearance, it makes up for in quality and cost.  

Today, it was just awful.  Me and a few friends went there to eat.

Service: I asked the person behind the counter for some steamed pork buns, right away she says they are out.   I am okay with this, as they are a popular item.  However, after I sat down to eat, my friend who ordered right after me sat down and pulled out a steamed pork bun.  Why does the person tell me one thing, when there obviously are steamed pork buns available?

Food: The food here is typically pretty good, especially for how little you pay.   I never go away thinking that I am getting what I am paying for.  However, today, I experienced the worst dim sum eating experience I have ever encountered.  I order sui mai, ha gow, and dumplings.   The sui mai was good per usual - no complaints there.  The ha gow and the pork dumplings were a different story.   These two items are usually pretty good here: you can see the pink shrimps in the middle of the ha gow, and the dumplings savory morsels to eat.   The ha gow I had today were a brownish pink color and did not have a very fresh taste or look.   The pork inside the dumping had the texture of oatmeal, and was the worst dumpling I have ever had.  Not a single bite of the ha gow or dumplings would be anything I would call savory, delicious, or something I would go back to the bakery for.

Again, usually they are pretty good.  However, today their food and service was awful.


Edit: spelling is hard.
author: Allan J.

description:
Well..... Idk...... 

My friend picked up some food here and I tried dim sum for the first time....

It wasnt bad....but I didnt know what to expect, and in my opinion it wasn't really all that good either. 

I just tried actual Dim Sum last night and it definitely didnt compare to the shrimp dimsum that I tried.

There are SO many places like this....Id just recommending going somewhere else
author: Julia D.

description:
The service is very fast and friendly. Had the best sesame balls here. It's crunchy enough on the outside and the paste inside is not oily and just sweet enough. I also tried the veggie shrimp dumpling-- not so good. It was too oily and barely any shrimp. I think it was shredded bits of shrimp. 
I'll have to try the other dim sum options and report back. 
Plenty of seating. I'll for sure get my sesame ball fix here.
author: San C.

description:
Awful!  I would give negative stars if I could. 

Intended to go to T C Pastry, but unfortunately they are closed on Tuesdays. So, I crossed the street and went to Happy Bakery. 

I ordered a baked pork bun and shrimp chive dumplings. The dumplings were filled with chives a one small piece of tiny shrimp and was cold - uneatable and tasteless-yuck! 

The pork bun tasted of chemicals like they didn't completely rinse their cooking equipment... 

I will never ever buy food from this place again! 

Stay away!
author: Steve L.

description:
Um yum!  Dropped by here and grabbed a whole bunch of dim sum to go.

Xia Jiao- pretty good but skin is a bit thick
Sau Mai- lots of meat and tasty
Fish Dumplings- pretty yum too

The winner was the Cha Sau Bau (BBQ pork bun) which makes up 2 of those 4 stars!  Soooo yum!  Big and full of meat even cold I was gulfing it down.

If you ever come here make sure to get this!
author: Esther S.

description: Found another to go dim sum place, the food was better than GoodLuck Dim Sum. The prices are abt the same. Happy Bakery was closer to me, will definitely go back when I am up for some dim sum...
author: Phil L.

description: Rude service and the pastries aren't even that good.. Didn't even want to give it 1 star'b
author: Angela H.

description: We are very unpleased with the quality of the dim sum here. My friends and I ordered the banh bao and hakao and it was not crackin. Never coming here again. They don't even have plates
author: Mia N.

description: Want some good, Hong Kong style dimsum? You can get some here! Living in SoCal, I've been deprived of the dimsum that I love. The prices have definitely gone up, but it is to be expected. The quality seems to be pretty good here. You're for sure going to get some tasty stuff! Their ha gow doesn't fall apart like it does at many other places. It is also full of flavor. Their siu mai is just ok, though. They have, what looks like, wheat baos with yummy chicken in it. They also have a giant bao with Chinese sausage, chicken, and shiitake mushrooms. It's really good and filling. I HELLA love SF!
author: Aaron Y.

description:
I like happy! 
The place is split into 2 sides, the right side is the lunch food side (meats, vegetable, chao faan) and the left side is the bakery with all the dim-sum y food. The lunch spcial is a steal on the restaurant side, it's like 4sum, and you get rice with 2 dishes, generous portions and pretty good food.
From the bakery: 
I really like the lai wong bao, the custard is cooked to perfection! not too runny not too hard. I also like their lo mai bao, which a lot of bakeries don't even have these days!
author: Antonio W.

description:
Dim sum is delish here! My favorite place to get haw goa (shrimp dumpling). Also...There are ready to eat goodies on the other side. Their fried chicken drumsticks are moist and yummy! I always order a big pan for parties and potlucks. Another yummy dish is the sweet and sour chicken. 

Surprisingly the customer service is not bad for an Asian store.
author: Jo S.

description:
The sight of Happy Bakery entices me every time I walk down the street to the market and back. On one side they have the standard chinese takeout that you can pick & choose from, and on the other side there's the baked/steamed goodies. The entree side is mehh but cheap & affordable if you really need a quick Chinese takeout fix. 

The bakery side is just so great and quite inexpensive. Steamed buns filled with whatever you want (beans, chicken, bbq pork, combination, etc) are less than $1 each. Can't complain with that price! They have tons of other options too. I personally love the red bean sesame balls (3 for $2) but wish they were a tad bit cheaper.

I'm so happy to have Happy Bakery in our neighborhood!
author: Andrew T.

description:
I'm reviewing the other side of this place that isn't dimsum (the entree section).

Came here yesterday because I wanted some cheap chinese food. My boyfriend and I come here and got lucky to find parking right in front of the place. He usually orders for me so I've never been to the place. I ask, "where is it?" and he says "right here!" *points right in front* It's a hole in the wall. Half of the place is dimsum and the other half is for entrees and stuff like that. I ordered their 4.60 something +tax with two items, which is a flat 5$ in total. I wanted fried rice, but it seemed like they only had chow mein and the thin noodles. My boyfriend asks in chinese when they'd have the fried rice out, and she said they aren't going to make it. She wasn't friendly but she wasn't rude either. I had to get the oily chow mein and I got sweet &sour chicken. I usually enjoy their sweet &sour chicken but this time.. it was not fresh. Then again, I came at 3PM and it's the type of places where they make it then just warm it up.

Overall, it's decent and I like the price.
author: Julian Y.

description:
There was a Chinese lady in the counter.

I asked," Can I have a bbq pork bun?"
The lady replied, "HOW MANY!" 
( her voice wasn't sound asking me though.}
I was like, " ?. one. please."

And I asked," Can I have a chicken bun?"
The lady replied, "HOW MANY!"
I was like, " ?. one. please."

And I asked," Can I have a pork and vege bun?"
The lady replied, "HOW MANY!"
I said, " ?. one. please."

So, i got 3 kinds of buns.
All steamed buns. 
I can say that all buns are pretty big and very tasty.
90 cents each!
I really like them and made me pretty happy.
But, the lady seemed not.

This is what the regular Chinese take out should be.
author: Nobu K.

description: I have to agree with a few yelpers: this place should be renamed Unhappy bakery. Every time I come here it seems I am deliberately ignored while the 3-4 ladies working behind the counter look past me as if I'm a ghost. I don't mean to be rude so I usually stand there and wait patiently until one of the ladies makes eye contact with me.... but that doesn't even work! They see me, and they"re like, 'oh look, we have a customer, let me just turn and face the wall for a bit'.
author: Amanda C.

description:
This is the spot to grab your typical Dim Sum items mainly to go, unless you're feeling adventurous and want to grab a seat for a quick meal. My orders normally come from the dim sum side, and don't really look at their lunch/dinner items unless it's the fried chicken and I'm searching for greasy food.

The Har Gow (Shrimp Dumpling) has good big pieces of shrimp that I cannot find fault, and it has become the dumpling I compare other dim sum restaurants with. 

Shu Mai (Pork Dumpling) is chock full of meaty goodness with no shrimp to take up space (that's why you order the Har Gow).

I've tried their Lo Bak Gou (Fried turnip Cakes), but realistically they should be eaten fresh right off the grill/pan for that extra crispy goodness. So feel to fry them at home if you're not feeling lazy. Their Pei Dan Sau Yuk Jok (Pork and 1000 year old egg congee/porridge) is delicious and I normally grab a Yau Ja Gwai/You Tiao (Chinese Donut) to eat in my corner. Lo Mai Gai (Sticky Rice wrapped in a lotus leaf) is also a good to go item if you want to ditch the fork/chopsticks. Buns (Chicken, BBQ Pork etc...) are more delicious steamed here, but I've yet to try their baked items because I'm partial to another restaurant for those.

I never feel rushed when I enter Happy Bakery, but I feel the need to order quick, and rush quickly home or wherever so I can nom my food in peace. The ladies definitely have their regulars and one should be prepared with what they want to order when they are called upon. Pictures and names of their items are displayed, but I am unsure how well their English is, ha-ha...They do have a real good baseline of dim sum for those in need to satisfy their cravings, but I will give them an extra star because of my loyalty to come out just for those shrimp dumplings.
author: Casey L.

description: Come here so often to get dim sum for breakfast. Nothing that is WOW so 3 stars.
author: Teresa C.

description:
The lady who took my order had no people skills or politeness whatsoever and her demeanor was quite indifferent. I even smiled at her the second time I went up to the counter to order more food and she stayed stoic. I'm usually ok with the subpar service because I can't expect great customer service at a Chinese restaurant but her aloofness bothered me. It was almost rude.

Food:
Suima: Really good
Rice Balls: Good
Potstickers: Good but already hard and cold
Egg Custard Bun: Too much bun not enough filling (would not get again)
author: Helen L.

description:
Came here to pick up some baked cha siu bao before heading back to the Central Valley (where unfortunately, there aren't a lot of places to get some good buns). 

Prices here are cheap and you have a good variety of eats. It is a plus to speak some Cantonese here (luckily I had someone for that!) Would love to come back here and try some of their other buns.
author: Tracy Joy K.

description:
Yes, the parking is pretty hard to find, but I can't blame the restuarant for that, it is Irving afterall. And yes, thier service COULD be understood as rude,but I personally don't think so. I think its just a different culture from American culture. In America, everything is so nice and slow and polite, there, its get in, get your stuff, and get out. When you're in a hurry, trust me its pretty convinient that they save you the B.S and just get to the point. You say what you want, they ask how many, you tell them, they give it to you, you pay them, you get food fast, they get money fast, everyone's happy. 

Food wise, it's alright, I mean its about the quality that you can expect for the cheap prices you pay. I'm sure there are better dim sum places out there, but this one is convinient. I like it.

Minus one star because the food really is just Alright, if it was CRACKIN' dim sum for that price we'd see 5 stars from me, but since its okay, they only get 4.
author: Elizabeth Z.

description:
Seriously good Dim Sum.

After visiting two other bakeries in search of Soy Drink (Sun's did not have it and neither did the other place on Irving) we finally found it at Happy Bakery.

Their BBQ pork buns, while smaller than Sun's, are fresher and tastier. At 3 for 1.60, I'm pretty sure they're cheaper too

I'd come back here anytime.
author: Meg T.

description: I walked pass by the bakery, so decided to pick up something for dinner. I bought 4 stuffed tofu. I didn't come here for 5-star services or food. Just wanted a quick bite. When I took a bite at home, the tofu was spoiled. This really pissed me off. I got nothing to eat for the night. Food is not fresh here. Will not come again.
author: J L.

description:
ok straight up I'm on this tapas tip right now....dim sum, izakaya, yakitori, ..you name the small dishes i'm on it like gromit. .

my friends and  I were on our last night of our Yay area tour and we were staying at the homie-gs house down the street. So I gotta give it up to our host , aka Carsons finest transplant ms. sangria. She said if you're hungry in the morning theres this bakery, good for dim sum and prices are dirt cheap. So i took the bait woke up early at 630 because thats when they open and went.

No line. No wait. No Problem. I believe the bakery is broken up into two counters one for the DIM SUM which I came for, and two for the noodles, tempura, and rice stuff.

Everything straight up on the dim sum side is 3 for 1.80 , except for the siopow. (steam or baked) is like a buck or two. still bomb tho and "HELLA, HECKA," cheap (sorry i was breaking into my bay personality) anyway. A must go for cheap eats, quick eats...especially if you're chillin in the outer sunset area of SF!!!!!!!!!!

The cheapest delicious dim sum you can find in sf.
author: Mike P.

description:
Reminds me of the shops I hit during my 10 years as an expat kid in Saigon and Singapore. I'd give it a full 5 stars if they offered HongKong tea like TC across the street, but they don't. Aside from the good buffet selection across the room, I mainly come here for their combo steamed bao, which is to die for with chicken, lap cheong, shitake mushrooms, boiled chicken egg, the rest of the normal veggies and spices for a chickent bao. If anyone can tell me of a place that offers a large mega combo like that, let me know! The nor mai gai (steamed rice and meats, wrapped in lotus leaf) isn't that bad either...and everything's inexpensive as hell. 

BTW great review by Scott A., lol: I don't come here for the service, either, though if you can practice a little emotional aikido with the female palace guard, you can leave with a smile, too. ;)
author: Cork G.

description: I used to get some dimsum, pastries and lunch combos here from time to time. Then I noticed some disgusting things. First was the dimsum. The ingredients in the dimsum was so disgusting and not fresh! How can they sell this to people?? Second thing I noticed was the stench from a guy who works behind the scenes (making the food?). If he reeked that much imagine what could go in the food. How can they let someone like that be anywhere near food? Third thing I don't like is how greasy and msg loaded the lunch items are. After I finished eating I felt nauseous and my mouth was so dry. No thanks, will never come here anymore.
author: Carmen L.

description:
With lots of time to kill in the Sunset, we decided to try here since we were a bit hungry.  You can order dim sum, buns and other hot food from steam tables.  

We ordered some siu mai, shrimp dumplings, BBQ Pork Buns for dim sum and Sweet and Sour Pork with fried rice and chow mien from the steam tables.  

The siu mai were OK, and full of meat and not very salty.  Just like anything else, they were made better with chili sauce.  Most siu mai has shrimp in it, but these don't, so that makes them better in my opinion.  The shrimp dumplings were scarfed before I could get anything.  That must tell you something.  I didn't care much for the pork buns, while filled with meat, they were too sweet.  The sweet and sour pork with fried rice and chow mien were also just OK.  Prices are not bad at about $1.50 for 3 pieces of dim sum and less than $1 each for the buns.

Not too much in the way of seating but most people get their food to go.  Not the best dim sum, but worth a look.  I will be back.
author: Michael M.

description:
Happy Bakery has two sides - the one on the left for dim sum and the one on the right for deli food.  I've never tried the deli side, so my review applies to the dim sum side only.

Like most other dim sum shops in the Sunset & Richmond districts, dumplings are 3 for $1.50.  The selection at Happy Bakery isn't as wide as Mongkok's, TC Pastry or Jook Time - they have about as much as Gourmet Dim Sum.  The menu is in English and there are pictures for some items, so it shouldn't be too hard to get what you want.  

They have Chinese rice tamales, egg custard tarts, steamed cake, baked buns (90 cents each), steamed buns, wife cake, mini moon cakes, rice rolls, etc. - your standard takeout dim sum items.  

I've been here a couple of times.  I have to say that I was pleasantly surprised by what I had today:
* Porridge w/ pork & preserved egg (rice soup on the menu) - nice and thick, surprisingly good flavor though low on preserved egg & pork.  No scallions or ginger used.  The chunks of pork are too big though.  Pork needs improvement (marinate it? Use a different cut?). Good Luck Dim Sum still has the best dim sum takeout porridge but Happy Bakery isn't too shabby.
* Har gow - larger than average with 3 or 4 medium shrimp per dumpling.  More shrimp than you usually get, nice flavor, not too salty.  Skin is thicker than usual.  Served warm.  Quite good!
* Steamed chicken bun - I like how they use big chunks of chicken, scallions and shitake mushrooms.  Could use more mushrooms but the flavor was quite good.  Decent amount of filling.  

Those three items totaled $4.70.  Cash only.
author: Lolia S.

description: Cheap and easy but not as good as TC pastry across the street.
author: Misha T.

description: Their har gow and siu mai never fails! I love it! Always so fresh, plump and juicy. Oh yea they are reasonably priced. When you're craving dim sum and don't want to go so a legit sit down restaurant, this place will always come through.
author: Vanessa K.

description: Not a destination dim summery, but perfectly acceptable in an "I'm hungry and in the neighborhood" kind of way. And cheap! $1.50 an order for 3 pieces for most items.
author: Gwynnie P.

description:
Happy bakery is my go to place for take out dim sum. Their har gow doesn't taste soapy like most of the other take out dim sum places and their fried dumpling is the BOMB! 

There's two sides to happy bakery, the dim sum side and the deli side. 

The deli side offers rice plates and a la carte items. Our church has them cater for us every weekend. Their items are all reasonably priced and their fried fish fillet is heavenly!
author: Jess s.

description: Bleh.. This place is alright.. Not the best, just alright.. I intended to go to TC pasty which is my "go to" spot, across the street, but I guess they're closed for vacation since I went on a Wednesday.  The chicken dumpling I ordered left a bad aftertaste in my mouth.  Hopefully, I won't get sick.  Unfortunately, I won't be going back to this place.
author: Larry D.

description:
I've been to this place off and on for a year now.  Although the dim sum has been pretty good and cheap (siu mai, shrimp dumplings were the better items), I'm giving it two stars for a couple of reasons:

1) I got a pork bun where the pork was not cooked all the way through.  The shrimp dumplings (har gow) was also not fresh this time as well.  
 
2) The service is terrible.  There is one lady in particular who is incredibly unpleasant- she doesn't want to explain what the item is (or even to open the steamer to see what's inside!) and gives you grief when you give her larger bills like $20.  

After getting the uncooked bun, I don't think I will be returning to Happy Bakery ever again.  I can deal with decent food with subpar service, but not subpar food AND service!
author: Linda Z.

description: I especially love the potstickers here but everything else is pretty similar to all the other dim sum places on Irving Street. What some people love (and I haven't tried) is the fast food to go next door (same restaurant). It's like $4.50 for 2 entrees and rice which is a pretty good bargain. Maybe I will have some next time. Maybe...
author: Wilson T.

description: Gosh, I miss bakeries like this down here in LA. Everything's way too frou frou and expensive here. They put everything in fancy little plastic bags and charge over a dollar for one bao or bun. Here, stuff comes straight from the oven or steamer on trays to the box or bag for you to take home. And it's so cheap. The BBQ pork and chicken buns are 90 cents. The cocktail and pineapple buns are 60 cents each. So cheap. There's not too much custard filling in the cocktail buns - but I always find its either too much or too little. There are no places that put just the right amount for me. The pineapple buns are kinda plain but that's the appeal of them, right? And I love the BBQ pork buns - steamed or baked. The meat is actually meat - not too much fat and it fills the entire bun. Not the best but very very good.
author: Alison W.

description:
I love this place.


Its cheap and pretty good dim sum.  Not the best, but pretty good, especially for the price.  For $7 bucks my bro and I pigged out and still had food left over.  If your broke and need food, this is certainly a good place to go.  Ordering in English can be tricky, if that's all you speak, I suggest pointing :)
author: Jen K.

description:
Today the dim sum didn't even make it home!
I scarfed them down in the car with no soy sauce or hotsauce!

I can't remember once I've eaten dim sum with no sauce. This had to be the first time. I've been coming here for years, they have always satisfied my dimsum cravings. Also their Chinese food on the other side of the store is also good.
author: Tip S.

description: I had gone there at last Sunday morning again.I bought a deep-fried dough sticks and a rice porridge with duck egg and pork.and then I chose a seat sitting and eating my brunch.I found the rice porridge was made by  last day.they are not new.and a worker put her food at my dining table and then pick them up.it took me unhappy .
author: H S.

description: I Like to come here when i am nearby Happy bakery. they have some great Chinese tastes still they make nice baked goods. affordable and good.
author: William I.

description:
happy bakery has both a deli section and a dim sum section. 3 cantonese ladies service the dim sum section alone.

dim sum review only:
-har gow (3/1.50): pretty large har gow with broken shrimp pieces within. tasty but probably msg enhanced. better than average.
-steamed chicken bun (.80):big fluffy bun with multilayed white meat within. some boiled egg pieces also. a little dry though.
-steamed pork bun (.80)large fluffy bun with bbq pork mixture within. bbq pork tender and not gristled. sauce ok

leftovers
-actually 3 1/2 stars cuz 1) har gow not whole shrimps 2)chicken bun a little dry
-metered parking available in mornings. afternoons iffy.
-fast, friendly service.
-probably cash only
-tax included in posted prices.
author: Victor G.

description:
OK people - lay off the bad reviews of this little shop of goodness. Sure the ladies behind the dim sum counter are a tad bit surly - but they do have to deal with some pretty tough old ladies that have been standing in a long line! 
I come with a big smile and a friendly attitude, and most often it is met with the same - except for the one tall gal that has been there forever (you know who I'm talking about) - she even will say goodbye to me - on occasion. 
But it is the food that we come for - awesome dim sum - and solid Chinese fare on the other side of the building - think fried chicken or rolled rice noodles. 
The gow is really good - coriander, shrimp, pork, mixed - all for $1.50 for 3 pieces. The pork buns are hot and fresh. The hot tea is free. 
And if you sit in the back and watch all the people coming and going - the show is priceless!
author: Scott A.

description:
This place serves surprisingly good dim sum for cheap.  It's your typical to-go joint but they have tables there for you to eat.  Their dim sums are $1.50 for 3 pieces (except the buns which are like 80 cents each or something)....I think this place is better than those in SF china town.

Aside from the to-go dim sum, they also have steam table chinese food on the other side which I did not get to try yet but the food looks pretty decent.
author: sonya h.

description: I usually eat dim sum at restaurants and not take out bakeries. However, I have a big sweet tooth. I love the sesame balls and the black bean lotus cookie. I would love to try their sponge cake and rice/ tapioca cakes next time. I am glad that I work so close to Happy Bakery :)
author: Rosanna T.

description:
The food is gross and the service is bad.
It is cheap, I'll give them that...
author: Patrick S.

description:
Nearly the best dim sum for the cost.

I can't believe we all ate for so cheap and yet is was soooo yummy!
author: Rebecca Y.

description: If you want delicious super authentic Chinese food for next to nothing...Go Happy Bakery. They have the biggest Shu mai I've found anywhere. The sticky rice balls are delicious as well as the fried salted shrimp. If you want Dim Sum in SF and you haven't been to Happy Bakery you need to go ASAP
author: Reuben R.

description:
+ good pork/veggie buns, fried meat dumplings, bbq pork buns, and har gow (haven't tried much outside of these things)
+ decent prices
+ best place on irving
- rude staff
author: Daniel C.

description: $5 for special combo.  That's pretty good deal for rice and two choices.  I usually ordered the broccoli and beef but I wanted to try something different for the moment so I gave the orange chicken a shot.  The orange sauce on the chicken was overpowering! I could not handle how sweet/sour it was at the same time.  I ate majority my mushroom with chicken balls. and rice that had barely any orange sauce on it.  Even though one of their dish taste horrible, I'd still come here for the price! Before it was only $4.80 now it went up to $5 but not bad for large portions.
author: Sharjah M.

description:
What happened to all the bakeries that have their pastries at around 60cents!?!?!?!?!?

I wanted to get a BBQ Pork Bun for my brother and myself but only ended up getting one for him because I was turned off by the price - 90 cents. Was it expensive? No. Am i a penny pincher cheapo? Not Always.But knowing that Happy Bakery is about 50% more expensive at another place makes me not happy. 

On to the BBQ Pork Bun. The bread was decent, but the pork was shredded so thin that it seemed more like a paste. In other words, it was disgusting. I was glad I didnt get one for myself. Im sure the other foods there are pretty good and if I ever tried it, I just might raise them one star. 

But whats really funny is those of you who read this long summary about BBQ Bun that cost less than a dollar.
author: Dorian T.

description: Lots of choices at cheap prices! They have a bargain cheap menu where you can order 3 for $1.35. Everything else may be a little more expensive but still very affordable. Food is fresh and hot! Service was good and they understood English. Their meat steam rolls were not very impressive though. Instead of steaming the rolls with the meat, I think they steamed the roll, then filled it with meat. It didnt taste as good as the ones they sell at a restaurant or at Chinatown. But overall, this place is comparable to the Chinatown shops.
author: Janet E.

description:
I been coming here for the past 2 years or so. It's one of the best bang for buck in Sunset for dim sum and rice plate.

It combines a full dim sum parlor with a full cooked-food entree selection in one store. So you can get dim sum and cooked-food with rice or noodle. How convenient is that. 

The rice plate with 2 items is only $4.50 !!! Not many places offer that in SF these days.

I have to tell you this. The har gow here is one of the tops! I mean its actually authentic Chinese har gow! You could really really see and taste the authenticity and time that was put into making this classic Chinese dim sum. 

When a hargow has huge shrimp inside and the skin is transparent, then you know it is a REAL HAR GOW! Anyways, enough on the praise of har gow.

This place is the place to go for getting the job done at breakfast or lunch time. You will not be sorry. The food is plentiful when you get the 2 item entree rice plate. This place is where I got my lunch for the last 2 or so years after school before work. 

This is like the bread and butter restaurant. Get in and get out. Satisfied every time. And it lives up to it's name. Happy Bakery. :)

Believe me, it's the go to spot for no nonsense, straightforward, and decent lunch.
author: U L.

description: Food is decent, price is good; but I'm giving this place two stars because the service is bad.  The ladies that work the counter are just rude.
author: E F.

description:
I came here on a late afternoon, starving, cuz I had early lunch.  Anyhow, I am a pretty nice rater, but today I'm not feeling like a very nice person. The lady that worked at the dim sum side, is the most bitter person working there, she perhaps is having a crappy day herself, but I don't think she should act the way she did to me. I ordered the abalone, chive, taro dumpling, and a potsticker. Yeah I forget the names of the food, but lord have mercy do u have to slam ur bitterness on me... Ugh! Rude!
But overall, the food was alright... Although, I tasted a little funky taste! Better not mess up my stomache
author: Monika T.

description:
$4.80 for a 2 item rice plate. Probably the cheapest "full" size order you can get around the sunset district for under 5 dollars.

My order normally consists of the korean chicken and tofu. In terms of taste, it's really really good.

However, my only problem with this place is their ration. I notice they are really cheap when it comes to giving you food. Why did I say that? When they feel like they added too much onto the plastic to-go box, they scoop it out of your box and place it back to the tray. HOW CHEAP IS THAT. 

Come on, I'm asian and I know all about trying to save money and all that, but really.............. how much is one extra tofu going to cost you? 

In the end, this place is pretty good if you're looking for something cheap to eat for under 5 dollars. The only other thing I can think of to eat for under 5 dollars in the sunset district are Vietnamese sandwiches. 


P.S. If you know cantonese, try to talk to them in it ! Sometimes, if the servers are in a good mood, they might, and I do emphasize "might", give you more
author: Garrick L.

description:
Happy Bakery is not that happy.  No one seems even remotely happy to see me here.

The good:  Cheap!  Fast!  Quality is sufficient for the price you're paying.  Full array of dim sum with Chinese take-out side next door (same owners?)

The bad:  If you aren't pushy, Chinese, and old, don't expect to get served first.

I was in line and NEXT but an elderly Chinese woman who could speak Chinese said her order first and was served first.  Boo!  This would be a good time to use all that Chinese I learned from work!  Too bad shouting the words "DINOSAUR" and "PIRATES" would not help.

But it's fast and cheap so I shouldn't really complain.  If you go in the morning it's pretty easy to find metered-street parking.
author: Kimiko Q.

description: I tried this place out for the first time after a dentist appointment.  Knowing that I wanted to have soft foods, I was craving dim sum.  METERED PARKING around 1pm was decent. The place is CASH ONLY. If you need cash (like i did), there is a Wells Fargo bank across the way.  The dimsum was steaming hot and not overcooked for being in the steamer too long.  The steamed BBQ pork buns seemed a little store brought and thrown in the steamer.  Overall, great har-gow and shu-mai. Har-gow had just the right amount of shrimp and a soft wrapper.
author: Greg C.

description:
I realllllllllllllly like their food.  Despite their bad attitudes, and do not protect you from cutting customers...their food is num num num num num!

They were even open on Chinese New year DAY, when everyone else was closed.  We needed to buy something vegetarian, and they were the only place open.  It was good!  

After buying food on one side, my mom always buys me something sweet for dessert on the other side.
author: kim w.

description:
First of all, I know nothing in the least about Chinese food. Nada, Neit.

Last night there was a knock at our door at about 9 PM. What on earth? It was a neighbor from a couple of doors down distraught that her indoor cat ran out her front door. Having this happen to me and my sister in the past I shared my experiences and offered my printer so she can pass flyer's around. 

Fast forward to noon today, she arrives at my door, slips off her shoes and brings in pink bag after pink bag of hot food, and reports that she found her cat and was just so grateful for all of our help and concern. 

So now I am sampling this Hong Kong style food, again not having any experience in these flavors and textures. So far I find it delicious. I have about 12 different things to try, and so far the buns and pie things are really good. 

Perhaps I should bring her some of my mom's tamale's one day.
author: Amanda L.

description:
Better half and I just went for a late lunch down the street and wanted something sweet as a dessert. Quickly for boba, here for red bean sesame balls.  I couldn't resist and also picked up an order of har gow and as we were starting to leave, they were bringing out a fresh batch of fried chicken on the other side. 

red bean sesame balls: just right, not too oily, not too sweet. 
fried chicken: WOW. complete surprise - lightly coated, super juicy and flavorful.  I'd eat this every other day if I lived closer. 
har gow: yummy! i was too full and saved them for next morning's breakfast. still good!

Get the fried chicken - especially if it's fresh. You won't regret it.  I'm still drooling just thinking about it.
author: c e.

description: WTH, we found a long curly hair inside the custard bun. Nuf said.
author: Carol N.

description: Happy bakery is great for their lunch special which includes rice and 2 other items packed into a large to go box for around $5! Good quantity and quality for the price. They are not gourmet but very good for their price and fast service.
author: Clark P.

description:
I'm going to assume this is the right location for Happy Bakery since the other one has less reviews.  Tried their egg tarts, custard bun, and the lotus bean bun.  Their tarts were okay, the crust was too sweet.  Golden Gate Bakery still makes the best egg tarts hands down!  The steamed buns were really good.  I'm a fan of steamed buns and after having fresh ones today, it made my taste buds dance a little.

This place looked more like a take-out place, but that's okay.  Prices are affordable and the ladies that work there are polite and provide quick service.  There were a lot of other good looking foods, but I'll try them later next time if I ever visit.
author: Anne N.

description:
Came here for a quick bite yesterday. Half the restaurant serves dim sum and the other half serves Chinese food over rice or noodles. I only ate at the dim sum side of the shop - so that is what my review is going to be about. This is a quick take out dim sum place, not a fancy dim sum place. There are quite a few tables and chairs here so you can very well order to eat in - and sit and eat. You get what you want - if you don't know ask! The ladies working behind the counter are pretty nice and they were patient with me - esp since I kept going back and forth on what I wanted. 

- Dim Sum is 3 for $1.50 you can mix and match - I got the haw gow, sui mai, chives with shrimp, daikon cake - all which were pretty good. 
- Big Chicken Bun - One of my favorite things to get at these places. It's a literally what the name is. It's a steamed giant bun, filled with chicken, Chinese sausage, shitake mushroom, and an egg. ($1.30) 
- egg tarts (60 cents) wasn't bad - though I prefer the crust to be more flakier, the crust was more cookie like instead. The egg filling was good though! 

Overall the quality was not bad, and there was a nice constant flow of people coming in and out - so that's def. a good sign. A good place to come to get some take out dim sum!
author: Betty S.

description:
I come here almost two to three times a week. You wanna know why?

You can't be a $3.80 lunch special.

I got the sweet and sour chicken and Mandarin chicken. It comes with rice. I haven't really tried the rest of the selection but I'm sure you won't be disappointed.

Lunch specials starts as early as 10am and ended around 430pm. Be sure to call to verify. The number is 415-661-1386.
author: Stanley K.

description: I usually eat here, before I go to work.. or tired cooking at home. It is a cheap combo meal, for 5 dollars, your getting full already. It is 3 stars, because I wanted the restaurant be more clean and spacious. It is not right to have prepping in a dining area, or greasy sneeze guard and dirty place
author: Calvin Nicholei L.

description:
For $23.20, I bought: 
24 steamed chasiu bao ($11.20) 
12 pork siu mai ($5.60) 
4 baked chasiu bao ($3.20) 
6 dan ta ($3.20)  

I like that the buns here have big pieces of chasiu rather than small bits that they have in the place where my dad buys them in Milpitas. 

My grandma thought the pork siu mai was a little too salty, but I think they taste fine. 

Tip: If you're going to buy steamed buns to go, don't microwave them on a plate; they'll get really hard like a rock. Instead, put the bun in a ziploc bag with a little bit of water, and they'll steam in the microwave.
author: Amy D.

description:
The best place I know for affordable take-out dim sum that is at least as good if not on equal footing with most of those fancy-schmancy full-service dim sum restaurants, and almost as good as the best. 

Here's why:

1) High quality chewy yet thin and transparent-looking texture of the dim sum skins when appropriate (Har Gow - with and without chives),

2) The only place where I can find a Steamed version of taro dim sum (Wu Nai Gok)

3) Excellent Chinese Tamales (Douunng.. ) - almost like the ones my mom makes, only a tad BIGGER!

4) Steamed buns are perfect.  Good amount of meat filling, and not skimpy.

5) Great Chinese deli-style fried chicken drumsticks.. YUM.. 

6) The sticky rice burrito things wrapped in lotus leaves are very good here too.  Most other places OD on the rice, and barely have any meat filling, but Happy Bakery doesn't neglect putting in a decent amount of pork, egg and chinese sausage inside.  I can't think of a better place to get this stuff.
author: Harry W.

description:
Have you ever had dim sum that was hella greasy?  Like crazy greasy where you have two pieces of shu mai and you're full?  

I hate that shit.  Greasy dim sum is hella gross. 

So I went to HBC to feed my hangover.  I got three shu mai, three shrimp dumpling and two BBQ pork buns and three of those rice sweet sticky thingies. $5.60

Cheapo Depot!!

I get home and start to chow down and oh mylanta!!  This dim sum was so NOT greasy!!  No oily heaviness....but still lots of flavor.  Mmmm.....I lub it!
author: Jay H.

description:
I have to admit that whatever restaurant went in here, I'd give it one star.  Why?  Because I really, really miss Golden City, the previous restaurant in this location.  It really was incredible, was a family favorite for over 25 years, a place where we'd enjoyed many memorable meals and celebrated events large and small.  Their signature dish was Princess Prawns, and we are still mourning them -- still have not found anything that even comes close.  I wish I knew where the cooks went when they unceremoniously and without any warning closed Golden City....

But, back to Happy Bakery . . . I know it's cheap, but frankly, I'd rather pay a bit more for better quality.  I hate biting into a pork bow and coming out with a mouthful of pork fat!  I despise biting into shrimp har gow and having to pick the shrimp shell from my teeth.  I really get angry when I get an elbow or knuckle in a bite of chicken sui mai.  

I'd always suspected that there is one centralized factory in the back alleys of Chinatown (or maybe of the Sunset) where every piece of dim sum is made and then shipped out to all the restaurants in town, but Happy Bakery disproves my theory... they must be either making it there, or getting the "seconds" at cut throat prices.   

Plus, given the intense parking situation on that stretch of Irving, I'd say it definitely is not worth a special visit.  Maybe if you're already there, have only $3.25 in your pocket, and are absolutely starving to death it would be fun.  But do you want to risk the aftermath?  According to their most recent  (June '07) Health Dept. inspection, they rated a sad 76 rating (out of 100), due to some filthy practices.  

Here is a link:  http://www.cleanscores.com/3431/Happy+Bakery
author: Bevy M.

description:
Chinese fast food at it's best. A dim sum to go place with a wide variety of excellent dim sum at dirt cheap prices. I think I'll grab a bag full for trip back to the west side of LA.
