TIP: Try this place for catered party platers. Excellent quality and value. You could easily feed people for $3-$5 a head.
author: Scott M.

description:
Reasons to go here: Tasty and generous portions for a cheap price.  Sure beats grocery shopping and cooking at home.  

This place has a weird layout...it's split into two different sections.  One side sells dim sum, while the other sells your basic "panda express" style food.  For $3.50 you can get the lunch special all day (white rice w/ two items or chow mein / fried rice with one item).  You can also buy food by the pound starting at $3.00 and up.  My favorites are the egg plant w/ tofu and sesame chicken.  The chow mein is pretty good too.  

I've also tried the dim sum...they're just so-so.
author: hello k.

description: Love this place!  Good Quality Dim Sum, get here early before noon because the dim sum runs out fast in the afternoon and rarely anything is left at the end of the day.  Also helpful to have a dual pickup lunch spot just next door for any chow mein/rice and takeaway entrees.  Prices are competitive and all very tasty.  Since they charge by the pound for the lunch items make sure they don't overfill too much.  Lines are long for dim sum but worth the wait.  Bring Cash.
author: Peachie Y.

description: If old chinese ladies opened up a shop, this would be it! But srlys the food is awesome and the price is unbeatable! $4.38 for two items and rice?? It's authentic, but basic cantonese-like food, pretty amazing. The short ribs and the grilled chicken is really tasty.
author: Kevin L.

description:
Ok I'll start with what I think is good before I go to the very disgusting.  The dim sum is really good here.  I usually get the siu mai and the shark fin dumpling, which is my favorite.  I've tried a lot of other things, rice noodle rolls, shrimp dumplings, plus the rice plates on the other side.  I must say, it's cheap and tasty to me.

Now on to the disgusting... my friend told me he saw a mouse crawling along the food trays by the window around closing time when they started putting food away.  SICK!  Maybe this is gross, but I didn't see it and I still go here.  Is that just horrible?  I mean, how many more places can I eliminate from Irving street??
author: Stacey C.

description:
Food: Not the best...but hey its just food. I usually order their 2 item combo here which comes with a heaping amount of white rice and 2 items from their hot table. I tried the tofu, chow fun, string beans and bbq chicken. All items are just okay...not super tasty but hey, what do you expect for only $4?

Price: Cheap, 2 items plus rice for $4 or you can buy by the pound.

Service: Never friendly, get in and get out.

Location: Located across the street from Baskin Robbins I think. Parking available at meters.

Atmosphere: Would never eat in here, seems kind of dirty...I should really stop going here!
author: Miss H K.

description:
Dammmmn, this place is so cheap that it almost makes me aroused!

Dim sum is only a buck thirty-three for three pieces. That's three shrimp pot stickers, three custard pies, three sesame balls, or three pork thingies for only one hundred thirty-three pennies. Their buns (the pork bun is delicious) are only seventy cents. A quart of their porridge is under 2 bucks. And all of their stuff is way better than the dim sum you'll get in Chinatown.

Mmmm... Happy Bakery indeed.
author: Ben P.

description:
I was walking around Irving looking for a good place to eat with my mom and brother. And i was looking at yelp signs. Maybe i saw a yelp sign on there but then I forgot. Maybe i over looked and just ran in because I saw chicken wings.. Which is so me. But then I saw shrimp dumplings.   YAY. So i ordered both. Chicken wing's were NASTY. T__T The shrimp dumplings were okay, but the shrimp smelled.. smelled like they weren't washed! WAH. Then the chow fun, .. nice one guys nice one. I tasted nothing. N O T H I N G, I lied. I tasted something.. that something was the major burning hot sauce and soysauce I mixed together to make a burning sensation in my mouth.
You can always try somewhere else. .. i need yelp on my phone shitty.
btw, sticky, dirty, food on the floor NASTY.
author: Carolyn Y.

description: This place serves lousy dim sum and pastry! I tried their egg tarts (tasted a day old), coconut bun (i had better), beef in rice noodle roll (the rice noodle was so thick and came apart), BBQ pork bun (eh), chow mein (too oily) , and shrimp dumplings (this was the only thing that was average). This place is like a fast food dim sum joint, you get what you pay for and it's not the best dim sum you'll ever eat. For some GOOD dim sum try South Sea Village (a bit pricey) or Dim Sum King at Skyline.
author: A. T.

description:
My friend and I desperately needed to use the bathroom, so we ran in here hoping to find one. Before we used the bathroom, we had to buy something. I bought a strangely yellow, crispycrunchy cookie for 90 cents, and my friend bought rice cakes (?) before grabbing the bathroom keys.
Their bathroom is definitely not the cleanest; however, both of us came back to nibble on the very tasty snacks we had just bought. Good thing nature called, or else I never would have ran into this place.
While leaving, I saw that the bakery sold dim sum on the other side. I will definitely have to come back here to satisfy my dim sum cravings in the (very) near future. They looked delicious.
author: Carolyn K.

description: I don't know about now, but I know from my experiences that the ladies working behind the counter are so rude. It's as if they bring the mainland China attitudes with them here. That's too bad because my one encounter with the owner tells me he's pretty nice. The cooked food wasn't bad either, which also makes the case too bad.
author: H K.

description:
I used to like this place a lot. The workers don't even look happy working at a place ironically called HAPPY Bakery.

I guess I'm being a little biased since I once knew a nice lady that worked here. The prices are a little bit pricier than I remembered, and if I'm paying almost a dollar for a BBQ pork bun...where's the pork yo?
author: Annie S.

description:
This is one fo the many dim sum take-out places on Irving.

The dim sum is cheap, and obviously you get what you pay for. Dumplings such as Hai Gau (shrimp), and chives Gau all have thick wrapping, not particularly preferred in good dim sum...

But I do like the slightly spicy turnip cake and the sweet red bean rice cakes!
author: T L.

description:
For: A Pork Bun by Any Other Name

These pork buns are of the the more "dusted" persuasion, and subsequently have that sandpapery texture on the outside of the bun.  It wasn't as gritty as the rival bun at TCP across the street, AND it was much bigger!  Also more expensive, but larger.  Why is it larger?  To fit all of the swiney goodness contained inside.

The syrup on the inside was sparse, making the bun a tiny bit dryer BUT the red char siu pork shone through the insides of this bun like giant rubies in a doughy crown.  I have never seen such large chunks of swine in a pork bun.  And there was no gristle or anything, just perfectly tender bits of artificially dyed piggy in a modest syrup.  Not only was the meat perfect, but the char siu flavor was so strong that I couldn't taste any "normal" (not char siu) food for a couple hours after.  Just as it should be.

I would have given this place a "5" for such a porky performance, but I had to deduct a star for the weird texture.  Although, there was a dude there who made conversation about the Three Mile Island shirt I was wearing at the time.  Its not everyday you have a discussion about TMI with a stranger.
author: Thomas M.

description: I only ordered one thing here, Ha Gow, and it's enough to make me want to trek here and get some more:) Other dim sum places are failing with their Ha Gow. But Happy Bakery makes them so moist inside and out. The filling is also really flavorful compared to other places I've gone to. Yes, you're probably thinking how can you fail at Ha Gow, well go ask other places that AREN'T Happy Bakery.
author: Connie C.

description:
3.20 for beancurd rolls. These are my favorite.

The dimsum are 3 pieces/$1.50.

They also serve rice plates with two items for $4.15. 

This place is always bustling with people, the take out items are okay.  The dim sum are pretty good but my favorite is the beancurd rolls.
author: Jboogie L.

description:
This is a two part restaurant.  The east side door leads to a counter selling dim sum while the west side door leads to a counter selling Chinese buffet type food.  I usually go to the dim sum side because I can pick and choose what I want without having to order a bunch of rice.  Plus the service is a little better.  The buffet side sells 2 items and rice for $4.15 and is a reasonable price.  However, the service is poor.  The women working there act like they are doing you a horrendous favor by serving you.  Granted their working conditions are not superb, but with their attitude who would hire them for anything else.

The interior has several tables and are seldom clean.  If you are to eat there, you may have to wipe the tables down.  There are a limited number of tables, but when we went there today, 4 of the tables were occupied by the help.  Each was occupying an entire table making the patrons wait.

The food is adequate and filling, but unfortunately it is a negative stereotype of Chinese people and restaurants.  The management or owners should let their staff know to treat customers with respect and that they are working in the U.S. and not in China!
author: Robert J.

description: Cha sui bao is pretty tasty. Ha gao was too starchy. Fun to speak to the ladies in Cantonese. Get baked cha sui over steamed for sure! Good in the morning to afternoon. Don't eat after 2-3 though--it's closing time!
author: Mike S.

description: The things that, I like most about Happy Bakery at Irving Street is the Dim sums and the Fried Chicken Drum Sticks that they have here and also the prices of the dim sums and other food items are very cheap!!! Happy Bakery is a very good place to buy your dim sums or other food items that you wish to buy!!!
author: William B.

description:
This place is my #1 choice for on the go dimsum. For $2.10 you can get a jumbo sized chicken bun (gai bao) and a dish of shrimp dumplings (har gow). Not only is it filling, but it is always fresh. I come here every week to either pick up breakfast for my team, lunch or a light snack for the road. 

Absolutely the best! oh, and did I mention..its hella cheap!!!
author: Jason C. J.

description: In between running errands in the Sunset district, I came across Happy Bakery, a hole-in-the-wall on Irving St at 24th Ave. Happy people working here? Not so much. Happy that dim sum to go rings up at $1.50 for 3? Heck yes.
author: Maybelle M.

description:
Been coming here forever, so I suppose this review is a bit biased.  The flavors of the dim sum are definitely there.  This is a traditional dim sum place so things are made a couple times daily and it's possible for some items to sit around for a bit, but for the most part the dim sum is pretty fresh and oh so delicious.  Only gripe is that sometimes stuff is greasy.

The most sumptuous item here is this shrimp(?) pork? pancake thingy that's stuffed with peas and other veggies, then fried in egg.  I don't know what its called, but I've had it at a few places in Chinatown and it's definitely the best @ Happy Bakery.  The sticky rice and buns are good too.  Super sad the old man's kids might not continue this place after/if he drops.  :/

Theres usually parking, a couple of ATMs across the street because this place is 'cash only' and and and there's a Quickly down the block because your sodium may be through the roof afterwards.  And yes, cheap.
author: Margaret L.

description: What can I say? It's a solid dim sum fast-food joint. As such, it is quick, cheap, and serves decently tasty items. It is A-OK with me.
author: Andrew P.

description:
Everytime it's cold and blustery and I feel a cold coming on, I make my way to Happy Bakery for their cheap and flavorful "jook" or rice congee/porridge. They have two big containers of it: one with thousand year old egg and the other with chicken. I always get the chicken jook and love it...with the ginger shreds in it and the taste, it just warms me up inside.

On other occasions I've tried their sesame balls (nothing beats the place from across the street...I'll find out the name), egg custards, steamed chicken bun, shark fin dumplings, shu mai and shrimp dumplings with leeks. All the dim sum items were good and reasonably priced. I was impressed with the size of the shu mai, the biggest out of most of the other take out dim sum places on Irving.
author: Janel Y.

description:
Cheap = good if you have things to worry about like rent and tuition. 

For $4 I can get a rice plate with 2 dishes..excellent. I like their fried chicken legs. The broccoli in the broccoli beef dish tastes great..but I can't say much for the beef as the lady only gave me one piece, the sweet and sour chicken is pretty good (or is it orange chicken? it's something coated in batter and deep fried), and the tofu with shitake mushrooms is just okay. 

What I don't like is the attitude I got from the scary pregnant lady. Maybe it's because I asked her (nicely, mind you) to repeat something I didn't get the first time around. I can barely understand two languages: broken English and fluent Chinese..not an advantage here I guess, as I can only speak two languages: fluent English and broken Chinese. I'll try the broken Chinese next time and maybe she'll be nicer..

Overall, the food is decent for the price you pay, but I think I've had better Chinese deli dishes from places on Clement, minus the attitude.

Edit 3/08: -1 star. Encountered scary pregnant lady again, this time armed with a booger that was threatening to fly out and land on my food. And still with aforementioned attitude! Stopped eating here for good.
author: Liz L.

description:
Excellent dim sum and entree dishes at dirt cheap prices. I came here to pick up food for six people and spent $36.64! Plus I had leftovers!

Items I love from the dim sum side: shrimp and cilantro dumpling, shrimp and leek dumpling, bean curd roll, red bean "cookie", and turnip cake.

Stuff I love from the other side: chicken balls (tee hee) with mushrooms, beef stew with turnips, big fried chicken, and little fried chicken.
author: Jacquee P.

description: One of those places where its highly probable your stomach will hate you for the rest of the day if not longer...  Everything tastes pretty good and the variety and price is competetive but Happy has missed a few finer details... I usually get the Shrimp Gow and a bbq pork bun if i stop by here... The noodle around the shrimp is a little thicker than I'd prefer and the pork bun is a really thick, syrupy mixture- not horrible (or i wouldn't ever come again) but I'd much rather have TC or Sun Maxim's.  Their takeout counter on the other side is pretty good for quick takeout chinese!  Great deals for their lunch combos! you can get like 2 items, rice/noodles for right around 5 bucks!  If its not a tuesday check out TC pastry right across the street, its my favorite!  Or Sun Maxim next to the Walgreens on Irving...
author: Bobby P.

description: If you have a hankering for a nice piece of cartilage then this is the place for you! They also sell out of the good stuff by 1:00 in the afternoon, but if it's an off day and they still have leftovers they're COLD. Not only is customer service none existent here, but they are also very rude. They refuse to acknowledge your presence, even if you are the next person in line. To second another yelper, it seems as though if you or not "pushy, chinese, and old" then you will not get served. Is this the way to run a business?Screw "Happy" Bakery, there ain't a smiling face to be found there and there are plenty of other great dim sum places surrounding it that would be much more appreciative of your business. Miserable little establishment. TC PASTRY all the way.
author: Katie S.

description: Most of the dim sum is pretty fresh and good. It opens really early so it'll take care of your hunger in the morning esp. the thousand year old egg with pork porridge. Only negative is the one lady who is kinda grumpy and impersonal.. but most of the dim sum ladies are like that everywhere.
author: Patrick L.

description:
I'm eating the food from Happy Bakery as I write this review, so this is as accurate as a TV review. I work just around the corner, so this is the easiest place for me to pick something quick to eat. I can't say their establishment is clean, but it's passable. So far, no problems with the food. The service there is nothing more than your usual cynical Chinese folk that shun every customer that can't make up their mind, but don't expect too much from Chinese bakeries, they are mostly like this (unless you make friends with them). 

I just finished my Har Kow (Shrimp Dumpling) and Siu Mai (I don't know what this is in English) and I'll say this: Best bought fresh and hot. It's a little cold for the Siu Mai even when they were taken out of their warm steamers. Definitely had better. Next is my Lo Mai Kai (Sticky Rice with Chicken wrapped in a leaf). Unwrapping it might prove challenging as the leaf is easily two feet long, so give some room. As for taste, it's pretty decent. I say it's the right amount of flavor, so it's not too bad. They could be a little more generous with the fillings, but understand that Chinese culture believes in more rice, less everything else. 

Now to my usual fare. Every once in a while, when I'm hungry and need something quick, I would run down here to get their Char Siew Bau. I've tried both the steamed and baked and I honestly feel that the steam is more appealing. Couple reasons why: 1) the fillings compliment the bau very well, 2) the BBQ pork inside is usually meaty with the occasional fat, 3) it feels easier to eat, and 4) I like them steamed. This is probably the reason why I like to keep a high-enough rating, but whether you like it or not, I believe that the Char Siew Bau is one of the best things to get here. 

Now for the other crazy things that I tried here. The Cheong Fun (Steamed Rice Rolls) is one of my favorite Dim Sum dishes and I happened to feel like it at one point during lunchtime. I tried some here and I don't think I'll try it even again. Despite it's thickness, the Cheong Fun still breaks apart easily. I had Cheong Fun from other Chinese restaurants and those could maintain their integrity from the plate to my mouth. This one just doesn't want to hold itself together. On top of that, I ordered the Shrimp Cheong Fun, but hey! Where's the Shrimp! I found about 4 pieces whereas they could easily fit twice as much. Saving money on shrimp? I don't know, but I'm going to have my Cheong Fun elsewhere. 

I've tried the Po Lo Bau (Pineapple Bun, but there's nothing pineapple about it; it's just a name). Not bad. Decent size with decent portion of its cookie top. A little messy once it crumbles, but it's good either way. 

Now last thing to mention, I promise, is the counter just opposite of the Dim Sum, which sells regular Chinese fare (Rice, noodles, meat and vegetables). I've tried various combinations of their dishes and carbs and it's ok, if not mediocre. Point to note is that I felt like I'm gambling with my food as in one occasion, I found a strand of hair deep fried into my Sweet and Sour Chicken. And again, I gambled and risked my health and money by ordering it again in another time, but I found nothing. So order at your own peril! 

Quality of the food can be sporadic, but it's fair decent with the price for how much the food can fill you up. I'm just finishing the last bite of my Lo Mai Kai and it's definitely filling for me. Now whether you trust my taste buds is entirely your choice, which is the beauty of it, but if it wasn't for that Char Siew Bau, this place won't receive much of my attention.
author: Jeremy L.

description:
I stopped in here another day to get a few pieces of dimsum. Though the cafe and the bakery are connected indoors, they have two separate doors for traffic. While I drove past, there was a line developed for the dim sum. So I stopped in. The beef siu mai and ha gow (I will not pronounce har for good reasons, and it always ticks me off when people call it har gow). Anyways, it was the same as Wing Lee on 6th and Clement, and the taste was the same. But again, I'm not out here too often, and parking is not as convenient as Clement. 

However, if I were out here more often, I would love to stop by this place for my usual dim sum fix.
author: Michael C.

description:
This place offers a wonderful lunch special (White Rice w/2 items or Noodles w/1 item) for $3.80 total. Their side items are not greasy (thank you!!) which plagues other similar counter shops in the Inner Richmond area.  I would recommend the tofu/mushroom or the marinated pork skewers. 
The other side of the counter has their dim sum counter. I love their BBQ Pork turnovers. Flaky and sweet. TOO yummy!  They also offer Hong Kong Shark Fin soup to go in small and large portions. I'll have to try that next time.
Cheap and tasty. That's all someone can hope for when you're hitting the lunch gremlins.
author: Pauline L.

description:
I frequent this place about every week after I do my weekly runs at Sunset Super and the 22nd and Irving Market. It's not the absolute best quality I've had but it sure is the cheapest and it satiates my dim sum cravings just fine. Dumplings are 3/$1.40 and so I can basically get full off of less than $5. The place is blatantly no frills and makes no apologies for being that way, so why anyone would give the place one star and complain about not getting an "appropriate container" for three measly dumplings is a bit ridiculous in my opinion. 

Their har gow is plump and delicious, their siu mai is tolerable but only in small quantities and their bean curd rolls and sticky rice in lotus leaf are amazing. Also, on the other side of the deli is the Hong Kong Style "Shark Fin Soup." It is cheap (for a reason) though delicious nonetheless.
author: Clarissa S.

description:
On days I have time in the morning, I would drive by this place to pick up some black egg porridge for $2.00. This place is pretty good with a decent menu selection. On the other side of this store they sell the noodles, duck and the other typical chinese foods.

Try it?
author: Dao C.

description:
All that matters is I got full for $4.50.  Oh, and it tasted good along the way!

I got the special, two items and rice.  All the more reason not to go to chain places like China Express.  

Friends I was with got some Dim Sum items which were delicious.  Everyone enjoyed their lunch!
author: Levi B.

description: I've tried much of the dim sum here- chicken, pork, shrimp, shark fin- and all of it was kinda lousy. Not terrible, just not good. And their steamed sticky buns are also underpar. With all the great dim sum bakery's in San Francisco, I dont see a reason to come here.
author: David D.

description:
This is my SPOT on outer Irving to get some quick, cheap eats (2 item combos and/or dimsum).  I like it cus its right by my 2 banks, HSBC on the corner and Wells Fargo diagonally across the intersection...so I park in this area a lot.  When Im done with banking/ATM stuff, I sometimes head over here for my lunch/dinner.

I liked how they now sell the green onion pancakes on the dimsum side.  That banana leaf covered rice and meat meal-on-the-go thing they sell is also my fav.

On the 2 item combo side, I like how they usually change it up on different days (some things they always have, like fried chicken).  I admit, sometimes its a bit too oily but for the price, I can't complain.

I remember they used to sell the combos for $3.25 a few years ago, then $3.50, then $3.75.  I think its at $4.50 after tax now.

My regular place for Chinese takeout.
author: Gilbert C.

description: I like to stop at Happy Bakery whenever i'm in the area and looking for a quick bite to eat for lunch. This place serves dimsum on one section and a variety of hot food entrees which easily goes well with rice or noodles. I've never tried their dimsum here, but the take out lunch is cheap, fresh and tasty. They have trays that are full with string beans, chicken wings (soy sauce or deep fried), tofu, chow mein, chow fun and a bunch of other goodies. They also have a 2 combo w/ rice deal which is only $5.00 - cheap!
author: M W.

description: An instant 4 star for this one of a kind dim sum take out.  What I love is there is no msg in the dim sum,  size of the dim sum is far from being small,  prices incredibly affordable and this is only place where you can find some of the most unique dumplings and pastries not offered at any other dim sum pastry shops or restaurants. Try the corn with shrimp dumping,  cilantro dumping,  fried pork turnover and the chicken buns. Go next door and sample Happy Bakery 's take out deli. A must try includes ginormous soy sauce chicken wings,  crispy fried chicken drumsticks,  sticky rice with mushrooms and chicken,  Happy Eating!
author: Kitty M.

description:
this place is my gauge for every other dim sum spot! FRESH! FRESH! 
i get a to go order at least once a weekend and am never disappointed!  verging on addiction! those little steamed rice balls with dried pork are insane! congee for breakfast and couple mismatched items for lunch and your set for $5! perfect food! steamed BBQ buns are the best in the city!.its loud, steamy, and swirling with tiny Chinese woman delivering manhole sized platters of fresh dim sum to the steamers! if you dont know what you want just hold up $$ and say filler up, and they will hook you up!
author: Andrew F.

description: This is a pretty good place for grabbing a lunch to go. $5 deal for lunch. Pretty good price and you can choose your 2 entrees of food. Love their fried chicken
author: May N.

description: This is my girlfriend's favorite Chinese bakery so I'm giving it 5 stars on her behalf.  She gets me the combo buns and pork and veggie buns which are both pretty tasty and big.  I can't really distinguish b/t most Chinese bakeries so I'll ignorantly oblige with 5 stars.
author: Ricky S.

description:
* Review for the S&P fried chicken wings*

our group of friends LOVE the salt and pepper fried chicken wings - they add a kick of jalapeno too - these are great for munching on. we just order 10lbs for the super bowl (cost about $45) - and they were a hit. the wings were ready on time for pick up - which was great.

difficult to find parking so better have someone come along with you to stay in the car. also, the servers don't speak much english...
author: Joy A.

description:
bbq pork bun...
fat-to-filling content is 20%, pass!
bun is perfectly baked, soft chewy, pass!
filling is rather salty, no bueno...

shrimp leek dumpling...
juicy plump shrimp, pass!
leek contents sparse, no bueno...
author: Ethan L.

description: Absolutely not!  So I attempted to get some dim sum here.  I figured that I would try somewhere new.  I went in and was the only customer there.  I looked at what they had and decided on what I wanted pretty quickly.  Then I attempted to get the attention of the girl at the counter.  I swear she just stared right through me and wouldn't respond!  Then as if to add insult to injury some asian lady walks in and she helped her right away while I am standing right in front of her!!!!!!  Ugh.  I walked right out at that point.  I guess my money isn't good enough for them.
author: Kate B.

description: i dont know about the other stuff, but we only order the fried chicken drumsticks here.  for that, i give it the review of four stars.  its not southern fried chicken.  its not the colonels secret recipe.  this is good old fashioned chinese flavor, finger licking, tasty, crunchy good a&& fried chicken - ya hear!
author: I Be E.

description: Grab some dim-sum take-out to go after you've done your Asian grocery shopping at Sunset Super and the produce stores. Dumplings, har-gow, and shu-mai are all great.
author: Rob T.

description: Cheap. I suggest you stick with what you're familiar with. Ok with steamed chicken buns and shrimp dim sum. I wanted to be adventurous and had this white gelatinous dessert with red beans--it tasted like cleaning product! What is with asian restaurants lacing their food with cleaning materials? This isn't the first time. But since I come here infrequently I let this pass, since it may have been a one time thing. You definitely should come early, not in the afternoon, all the food was room temperature and had been out for a while. Decent egg custard.
author: Selina C.

description: Cheap Chinese eats!  If on a budget and you're into Chinese and in the Sunset check it out.  Definitely Hong Kong flavor...from the atmosphere to the employees., who offer up that usual HK Chinese service, i.e. here's your food, pay up and go on your way.
author: Ed M.

description: this is definitely not one of the best dim sum places in town... however, if this place was in Texas or some other non-Asian state, this place would receive higher rankings. Food here is rather mediocre. I'd rather go across the street to tc pastry. Happy Bakery's gai baos (steamed chicken buns) are okay.... their other  dimsums are rather bland. i'd recommend more use of ginger.
author: Colleen W.

description:
very average take out dimsum. i do enjoy some of the things on the menu...such as their EGG TARTS. i do have high standards when it comes to egg tarts and these are quite satisfying! i wish i could give this place a 3.5 stars rather than 4.. i mean i give so much 4s.. and 4 is considered to be HIGHLY recommendable. This place is very average, like i said! OK OK, I digress. Back to the foods.

I also got the fun goh. Not bad, but when I bit into it, I bit into something crunchy. Crunchy usually makes me think of bad things! (like cockroaches and ants). AHHH ;)

i'd come back still!! Long live their egg tarts!!
author: Bonita C.

description: This place is okay I guess . It's kind of cool how they have one side for selling dim sum and one place for selling rice and stuff . Also , this is one of the cleanest dim sum places i been too .. table & floor-wise . It is actually an okay place to dine . The turnip cake was okay I guess . The chicken bun was good . The prices are ehh .. kind of steep compared to Chinatown dim sum places . But yeah , their dim sum is okay but I've definitely had better . I would recommend this place for a quick cheap meal . I haven't tried their rice and side dishes but I'll definitely get to it next time when I visit and I will edit this review when I do .
author: Eileen L.

description: I have a steel stomach but this place always gives me runny shits.  The shu mai here is terrible.  They put a chinese style meat ball in a dumpling skin.  Freakin nasty.  I would eat here with caution.  Go to TC pastry down the street you skinny people.
author: Fatty A.

description: This place makes shrimp dumplings so well. Trumps all the other dim sum places I've been to. Whenever I want a har gow, which is my all-time fave, I have mother bring me some back from here. Quick & convenient! And I'm sure their other dim sum is well beyond decent as well.
author: Audrey T.

description: I'm sure that in this city and even in the Sunset you can find better Dim Sum... But on a Sunday morning and  with no line in sight, I had to try the steam pork dumpling and for a $1.50 for three- not bad...
author: swys -.

description: The prices for their combo plates have gone up to over $4 now.  You get rice and 2 entrees.  They have a pretty good variety of choices but the food can be inconsistent.  Tried the fried chicken wings which was decent as well as the drumsticks but not spectacular.  The chow fun was pretty good today but the thicker chow mein was bland.  Their black bean sauce pork spareribs is usually good. They make tofu dishes, bitter melon dishes and sweet & sour pork, which is usually a staple.  I feel sorry for the seniors on fixed income who come here, it's not that cheap for them. The black bean pork was over $4/lb and you're paying mostly for bones and ligaments.  This place reminds me of the old days in Chinatown where there used to be a lot of shops like this one with cooked food items that you could purchase for the family dinner.
author: Ry T.

description: I've been coming here to buy breakfast/lunch/dinner for the past few years. The dim sum and the buns here are better than TC Pastries. I like the ha-gow, shui mai, pinapple bun, chicken butt bun, rice tamales, pork bun (baked) and the sweet yellow filled buns. On the buffet side, I like the chow fun, broccoli beef, and their fried chicken-YUMMY! Affordable fast food!
author: Marcus Y.

description:
I'm a busy SFUSD parent have been very happy with repeatedly going to this place since they opened.  I've bought their food for family functions, picnics, and major school events (potlucks, PTA meetings, fundraisers, class parties, volunteer school events).  

I'm Chinese and my family has traveled to Asia repeatedly and the food is fine. It's authentic and not plastered with food coloring and tons of lumpy corn starch gravy. Every function that I bought the food for has been praised by other students, teachers, staff, and parents alike.  It's reasonable and I am always asked where I got it from. 

They love the Chow Mein skinny noodles, chow fun, fired rice noodles, and the fried chicken, broccoli beef, soy sauce chicken wings, etc...!  They all ask where I got it from.  I've been getting it for years here.  My school has many clean up days at school and they will come and volunteer just for the food alone!

Sure, the service is not always with a smile  It's cultural but don't take it personally.   The variety, quality, speed and the price is worth it.  Their native language is not English so their service is limited and similar to what it would be like in another country.  It is what it is; cheap price, fast food.  

I always order in advance and pick it up and go.  Usually I order stuff 10-15lbs at a time.  Dim sum is fine.  I love the vegetarian stuff, foo jook, eggplant, and jai.  Breakfast stuff...Chinese rice porridge, donut, sticky rice/ tamales wrapped in leaves all good.  The locals go here as well if you notice the other people waiting in line.  Try it.
author: Ruby T.

description: Decent Dim Sum and other  Chinese Food take out food.  I really give it 3 and half. The service is  friendly and prices inexpensive. I had better tasting dim sum though.  The other Chinese food on the other side seems a bit greasy for me. It's a nice place to have in the Sunset though and I appreciate it in my hood.
author: Leon C.

description: This is an ok place to get dim sum. The only thing that I enjoying getting from here would have to be the fried chicken and shrimp, maybe the Gai bao (chicken bun)
author: Maile W.

description: Incredibly unpleasant employees. If you don't speak Chinese, be prepared for rude service; if you do speak Chinese then you are in luck (for when you need to argue with them about overcharging you.) The food is semi-decent, but it just isn't worth the trip when there are other Dim sum places that don't treat customers with such contempt.
author: Lizy A.

description:
The Chinese equivalent to a fast food restaurant...the food is lousy and can make you sick, the people that work there aren't so friendly, but it's cheap and it's quick and at times that's enough for me to go there.
Plus they close way too early
author: Joe K.

description: One side has a pretty decent "steam table" lunch special for $4.50, definitely fill you up and some of the choices pretty good.  Other side decent buns, dumplings and other.
author: Todd K.

description: Happy Bakery has the best dim sum in the city. I can't get enough of their taro root dumplings (not fried). So yummy and fresh!
author: hey d.

description: I was here after a quick lunch on the same block. I love the egg tarts and their pasties. My go to place in San Francisco....Their food is very good and will return....
author: Alycesie L.

description: Cheapest rice plate in the city I reckon. $3.25 tax included for two items on a heaping mound of rice. I cannot finish one rice plate by myself, it is just too much food. if you are on a budget, eat here! Not worth coming all the way to the sun set just to eat here but if you're here shopping you ought to stop by for the cheap eats.
author: neal j.

description: My go to place for Chicken jook-the best in the neighborhood and for their har gow; yum!  huge shrimp that squirt out juices when you stuff the whole thing in your mouth and take a bite.  They have a sister bakery on Clement by the French Kaiser campus.  When you see a bunch of locals wait in line and have breakfast inside the small bakery, you know it's good stuff!
author: Patty J.

description: another solid cheap dim sum place. good pork and cabbage buns and shrimp dumplings. need to try other stuff next time.
author: Kan L.

description: I love this place. It's a totally typical dim sum place, but their stuff is good and cheap. It's becoming a regular for my sunday brunch. I don't know what it is, but it's addicting!
author: Mari K.

description: good food, awful people.  really, really awful people.  don't go there if you don't want someone to ruin your day.
author: annabel l.

description: i havent been to many of these places but this place sucks to me. i got the chow mein and fried prawns. and a baked pork bun.  the prawns were terrible and salty. i got the impression while eating it that they didnt change the oil in the deep fryer for a month or two.  the chow mein wasnt anything special and was greasy. i couldnt eat the whole pork bun beacuse it didnt even have that much pork in it... just gobs of bbq sauce. im not going back.
author: Wats C.
